tasks.title: Enhance genetic optimizer with one-time actions and automatic loan management
tasks.description:
Improve the genetic optimizer to test more diverse strategies:

1. **Increase one-time action frequency**:
   - Boost HIRE_ROOKIE probability from 20% to 40-50%
   - Boost BUY_MACHINE probability from 15% to 30-40%
   - Add FIRE_EMPLOYEE and SELL_MACHINE actions
   - Test combinations of multiple one-time actions

2. **Add automatic loan management**:
   - Before each action, calculate if it would violate minimum cash threshold
   - If yes, automatically insert TAKE_LOAN action before it
   - Calculate exact loan amount needed to maintain threshold
   - Ensure loans are only taken when necessary

3. **Smarter action generation**:
   - Remove overly restrictive conditions (queue > 5, NPV > 0)
   - Test more aggressive strategies (early hiring, early machine purchases)
   - Generate multi-action sequences (hire workers + buy machines + adjust prices)

Acceptance Criteria:
- Optimizer logs show HIRE_ROOKIE, BUY_MACHINE actions in at least 30% of candidates
- TAKE_LOAN actions appear automatically before cash-negative actions
- No simulation failures due to insufficient cash
- Action diversity increases (currently only seeing 5 policy actions)

tasks.title: Address high-severity security vulnerabilities in xlsx package
tasks.description:
The xlsx package has 1 high severity vulnerability:
- Prototype Pollution (GHSA-4r6h-8v6p-xvw6)
- Regular Expression Denial of Service ReDoS (GHSA-5pgg-2g8v-p4x9)

No fix available for current xlsx package.

Options:
1. Switch to alternative Excel library (e.g., exceljs, xlsx-populate)
2. Accept risk for internal development tool
3. Remove Excel export feature

Recommendation: Evaluate exceljs as safer alternative with similar API.

tasks.title: Fix standard product demand curve to reflect competitive market reality
tasks.description:
The current demand curve (Q = 500 - 0.25*P) is too gentle for the "very competitive" market described in the business case.

**Problem:** Users can charge $1,200 (6x market price) and still sell 200 units/day. This contradicts competitive market dynamics.

**Business Case Evidence (Page 2):**
- "The market for standard products was dominated by purchasing departments of large health institutions, and it was very competitive"
- "Executives... had kept prices below the market average"
- In competitive markets, pricing above market = near-zero sales

**Solution:** Implement steeper demand curve:
- Intercept: 1500 (up from 500)
- Slope: -5.0 (down from -0.25)
- Formula: Q = 1500 - 5.0 * P

**Results with new curve:**
- $200 (below market): 500 units/day (high demand)
- $250 (near market): 250 units/day (moderate)
- $300+ (above market): 0 units/day (competitive rejection)
- $800: 0 units/day
- $1200: 0 units/day

**Files to modify:**
- src/simulation/constants.ts (lines 185-186)
- Update standardDemandIntercept and standardDemandSlope
- Add comment explaining competitive market dynamics

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Pricing significantly above $300 results in near-zero demand
- Previous optimizer results ($1200 price) would now fail
- Realistic competitive behavior enforced
- Students learn operations management, not price gouging
